articles.headline: When Trying to Follow Rules Isn’t Enough
articles.snippet: As JPMorgan’s general counsel, Stephen Cutler tried to create a culture of compliance. The effort couldn’t stop the “London whale” matter and other regulatory woes.
articles.abstract: As JPMorgan’s general counsel, Stephen Cutler tried to create a culture of compliance. The effort couldn’t stop the “London whale” matter and other regulatory woes.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the Securities and Exchange Commission’s chief of enforcement from 2001 to 2005, the era of landmark fraud settlements with Enron, WorldCom and Tyco, Stephen M. Cutler earned a reputation as a tough and, at times, feared regulator. He was particularly dismayed by chief executives, chief financial officers, general counsels and compliance officials who, even if not directly implicated in wrongdoing, created a culture in which it was ignored, tolerated, or even worse, tacitly encouraged.

articles.headline: Navy Hearing in Rape Case Raises Alarm
articles.snippet: A case at the Naval Academy illuminates what critics say is wrong with trying sexual assault cases in the current military justice system, which is under scrutiny in Congress.
articles.abstract: A case at the Naval Academy illuminates what critics say is wrong with trying sexual assault cases in the current military justice system, which is under scrutiny in Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For roughly 30 hours over several days, defense lawyers for three former United States Naval Academy football players grilled a female midshipman about her sexual habits. In a public hearing, they asked the woman, who has accused the three athletes of raping her, whether she wore a bra, how wide she opened her mouth during oral sex and whether she had apologized to another midshipman with whom she had intercourse “for being a ho.”

articles.headline: Auto Leases Entice, but They’re Still Costly
articles.snippet: A car lease may seem like a steal, but it still costs several thousands more than buying a new car, not to mention a newish used car.
articles.abstract: A car lease may seem like a steal, but it still costs several thousands more than buying a new car, not to mention a newish used car.
articles.lead_paragraph: When you can drive a car off the lot with that new car smell for a mere $199- or $299-a month-lease, many consumers can’t help asking: How can I afford not to take this deal?

articles.headline: BlackBerry to Cut 40% of Work Force After Big Loss
articles.snippet: The embattled smartphone maker said it would report a quarterly loss between $950 million and $995 million next week, mainly the result of a writeoff of unsold phones and restructuring charges.
articles.abstract: The embattled smartphone maker said it would report a quarterly loss between $950 million and $995 million next week, mainly the result of a writeoff of unsold phones and restructuring charges.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — At their peak, just a few years ago, BlackBerry smartphones were symbols of corporate and political power. When President Obama took office he made keeping his BlackBerry a personal priority, and when BlackBerry service had a hiccup so did business on Wall Street.

articles.headline: Emmys Highlight a Changing TV Industry
articles.snippet: With its first nomination, for “House of Cards,” Netflix makes its mark on the Emmys, but “Breaking Bad” has the most buzz.
articles.abstract: With its first nomination, for “House of Cards,” Netflix makes its mark on the Emmys, but “Breaking Bad” has the most buzz.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Emmy Awards have witnessed many new players on the red carpet over the years, but there has never been a gate-crasher quite like Netflix.

articles.headline: California Gives Expanded Rights to Noncitizens
articles.snippet: California is challenging the status of citizenship with measures to let noncitizens sit on juries and monitor polls for elections.
articles.abstract: California is challenging the status of citizenship with measures to let noncitizens sit on juries and monitor polls for elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — California is challenging the historic status of American citizenship with measures to permit noncitizens to sit on juries and monitor polls for elections in which they cannot vote and to open the practice of law even to those here illegally. It is the leading edge of a national trend that includes granting drivers’ licenses and in-state tuition to illegal immigrants in some states and that suggests legal residency could evolve into an appealing option should immigration legislation fail to produce a path to citizenship.

articles.headline: Challenges Await Plan to Reduce Emissions
articles.snippet: A proposal from the Obama administration to limit carbon emissions might be curtailed in a legal quagmire if the required technology does not meet current standards.
articles.abstract: A proposal from the Obama administration to limit carbon emissions might be curtailed in a legal quagmire if the required technology does not meet current standards.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration’s potentially pathbreaking proposal for carbon emission limits on new power plants will face political and legal challenges from opponents who argue that the technology needed has not been close to being proven as the law requires.
articles.byline: By Matthew L. Wald and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Hacking U.S. Secrets, China Pushes for Drones
articles.snippet: A two-year hacking operation by a group linked to China’s army is the latest sign of Beijing’s ambitious plans to be at the forefront of drone manufacturing.
articles.abstract: A two-year hacking operation by a group linked to China’s army is the latest sign of Beijing’s ambitious plans to be at the forefront of drone manufacturing.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — For almost two years, hackers based in Shanghai went after one foreign defense contractor after another, at least 20 in all. Their target, according to an American cybersecurity company that monitored the attacks, was the technology behind the United States’ clear lead in military drones.

articles.headline: Santa Monica Bets on Electric Cars, but Consumers Are Slow to Switch
articles.snippet: For automakers, reluctance in Santa Monica, Calif., underscores how difficult it will be for them to meet strict federal and state mandates on fuel efficiency and pollution.
articles.abstract: For automakers, reluctance in Santa Monica, Calif., underscores how difficult it will be for them to meet strict federal and state mandates on fuel efficiency and pollution.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — It would seem to be a good time to own an electric car in Santa Monica. From the charging stations dotted around town to the dedicated public parking spaces — all provided at no cost by the city — Santa Monica has rolled out the welcome mat for electric cars.

articles.headline: Gunmen Kill Dozens in Terror Attack at Kenyan Mall
articles.snippet: Two squads stormed into a Nairobi mall Saturday, killing at least 39 people. Hours later, police officers dashed through corpse-strewn corridors, trying to find the assailants. A Somali militant group is suspected in the attack.
articles.abstract: Two squads stormed into a Nairobi mall Saturday, killing at least 39 people. Hours later, police officers dashed through corpse-strewn corridors, trying to find the assailants. A Somali militant group is suspected in the attack.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Masked gunmen stormed into a fancy, crowded mall in Nairobi on Saturday and shot dead at least 39 people and wounded more than 150 in one of the most chilling terrorist attacks in East Africa since Al Qaeda blew up two American embassies in 1998.
articles.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Nicholas Kulish

articles.headline: A Better Way to Compare C.E.O. Pay
articles.snippet: Peer group comparisons are probably more useful to investors than the new pay rule proposed by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
articles.abstract: Peer group comparisons are probably more useful to investors than the new pay rule proposed by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOW much pay is too much pay? It’s a question shareholders have been asking for years.

articles.headline: Ad Campaigns Compete as Health Law Rollout Looms
articles.snippet: As the Obama administration prepares to put the health care law in place, it faces an aggressive Republican campaign to prevent its success.
articles.abstract: As the Obama administration prepares to put the health care law in place, it faces an aggressive Republican campaign to prevent its success.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama waged a fierce fight to pass his health care law four years ago. But as his administration prepares to put it in place, he is facing an aggressive Republican campaign to prevent a successful rollout and deny him his most important legacy.

articles.headline: With a Tweet, Twitter Starts a Debate
articles.snippet: Twitter is the most prominent example of a company that is using the JOBS Act, enacted with the promise of creating jobs, to go public.
articles.abstract: Twitter is the most prominent example of a company that is using the JOBS Act, enacted with the promise of creating jobs, to go public.
articles.lead_paragraph: “LISTEN, do you want to know a secret? Do you promise not to tell?”

articles.headline: Roaring Waters, Deep Scars: ‘It Chewed Us Up’
articles.snippet: After flooding hit 17 counties in Northern Colorado earlier this month, affected communities are facing the prospect of a slow and expensive recovery.
articles.abstract: After flooding hit 17 counties in Northern Colorado earlier this month, affected communities are facing the prospect of a slow and expensive recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: JAMESTOWN, Colo. — In the Colorado mountains, the floodwaters struck Jamestown like an invading army. Houses tumbled into the churning Little James Creek. A torrent of rocks and mud crushed Joey Howlett, 72, in his home. People rushed into the rain in pajamas, children in their arms, to shouts of “Get out! Get out!”
articles.byline: By Jack Healy and Dan Frosch

articles.headline: For Migrants, New Land of Opportunity Is Mexico
articles.snippet: With Europe sputtering and China costly, the “stars are aligning” for Mexico as broad changes in the global economy create new dynamics of migration.
articles.abstract: With Europe sputtering and China costly, the “stars are aligning” for Mexico as broad changes in the global economy create new dynamics of migration.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Mexico, whose economic woes have pushed millions of people north, is increasingly becoming an immigrant destination. The country’s documented foreign-born population nearly doubled between 2000 and 2010, and officials now say the pace is accelerating as broad changes in the global economy create new dynamics of migration.

articles.headline: Intimacy on the Web, With a Crowd
articles.snippet: Pornography by webcam is a money-making opportunity in a business eroded by the distribution of free sexual content on the Internet.
articles.abstract: Pornography by webcam is a money-making opportunity in a business eroded by the distribution of free sexual content on the Internet.
articles.lead_paragraph: A 25-YEAR-OLD woman whose fans know her as Lacey or Miss Lollipop, neither her real name, dipped an index finger into a small glass jar. She scooped up a dollop of foundation makeup and spread it on her forehead and cheeks.

articles.headline: Wintour’s Reign Extends Beyond Vogue
articles.snippet: Anna Wintour has always been a big deal, but her influence within Condé Nast is now on the march in ways that are not just reshaping the magazines but the organization.
articles.abstract: Anna Wintour has always been a big deal, but her influence within Condé Nast is now on the march in ways that are not just reshaping the magazines but the organization.
articles.lead_paragraph: Anna Wintour created a bit of an international incident in 2010, when she cut short her visit to Milan Fashion Week. Designers scrambled, fashion journalists pondered its deeper meaning and local officials took grave offense.

articles.headline: Cutting Through the Cloud
articles.snippet: Corporate technology buyers are looking at a growing number of new and old tech companies to manage their systems.
articles.abstract: Corporate technology buyers are looking at a growing number of new and old tech companies to manage their systems.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Over the next few years, what happens to the several trillion dollars that businesses spend on technology will be decided by executives like Jeff Allen.

articles.headline: F.A.A. Nears New Rules on Devices
articles.snippet: Faced with the flood of personal electronics on airplanes, the government has spent the last year looking for ways to modify its policy and keep passengers safe.
articles.abstract: Faced with the flood of personal electronics on airplanes, the government has spent the last year looking for ways to modify its policy and keep passengers safe.
articles.lead_paragraph: The rules on when to turn off electronic devices on airplanes have long been a sour, and sometimes contentious, point for travelers. But faced with a surge of electronics on airplanes and under pressure from a growing number of tech-savvy — and increasingly tech-dependent — passengers, the Federal Aviation Administration recognized that change was inevitable.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Nick Bilton

articles.headline: Networks Go to Extremes to Promote New Shows for the Fall Season
articles.snippet: Broadcast networks have been challenged by a continuing decline in ratings, so marketing executives have left no stone unturned in the pursuit of promotional ideas.
articles.abstract: Broadcast networks have been challenged by a continuing decline in ratings, so marketing executives have left no stone unturned in the pursuit of promotional ideas.
articles.lead_paragraph: With a phalanx of new series to make their debuts this week against an increasingly dominant cable television lineup, broadcast television executives this summer turned to diverse promotional ideas.

articles.headline: Kenya Mall Carnage Shows Shabab Resilience
articles.snippet: The Shabab could be signaling a wider offensive, despite losses in recent years at the hands of the African Union and Kenyan troops in their home country.
articles.abstract: The Shabab could be signaling a wider offensive, despite losses in recent years at the hands of the African Union and Kenyan troops in their home country.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The ferocious armed political movement known as the Shabab is on the ropes in Somalia, losing territory and influence in its home country.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Kulish, Mark Mazzetti and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Law Opens Financing of Start-Ups to Crowds
articles.snippet: On Monday, federal legislation goes into effect to allow small start-ups to ask for equity investments publicly without having to register the shares for public trading.
articles.abstract: On Monday, federal legislation goes into effect to allow small start-ups to ask for equity investments publicly without having to register the shares for public trading.
articles.lead_paragraph: Entrepreneurs looking to the crowd to finance their big ideas just got a little extra help from the government.

articles.headline: Chinese Titan Takes Aim at Hollywood
articles.snippet: Wang Jianlin, reputed to be China’s richest man, announced plans to build a movie-themed real estate development in what he billed as China’s effort to become the world leader in filmmaking.
articles.abstract: Wang Jianlin, reputed to be China’s richest man, announced plans to build a movie-themed real estate development in what he billed as China’s effort to become the world leader in filmmaking.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Los Angeles has film studios and the best-known movie industry award ceremonies. Orlando has amusement parks and resort hotels. Now, one of China’s richest men wants to copy them with a movie-themed real estate development in his country’s most fashionable beach city.

articles.headline: Give Yourself 5 Stars? Online, It Might Cost You
articles.snippet: A yearlong investigation by New York regulators has resulted in the most comprehensive crackdown to date on deceptive reviews on the Internet.
articles.abstract: A yearlong investigation by New York regulators has resulted in the most comprehensive crackdown to date on deceptive reviews on the Internet.
articles.lead_paragraph: “I celebrate myself, and sing myself,” wrote Walt Whitman, America’s great bard of self-promotion. As the world goes ever more digital, quite a few businesses are adopting that philosophy — hiring a veritable chorus of touts to sing their nonexistent praises and lure in customers.

articles.headline: A New U.S. Player, Put on World Stage by Syria
articles.snippet: Samantha Power, the American ambassador to the United Nations, will be on the spot as her performance at the General Assembly this week will help determine the country’s future course in Syria.
articles.abstract: Samantha Power, the American ambassador to the United Nations, will be on the spot as her performance at the General Assembly this week will help determine the country’s future course in Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Nearly a year before the world woke up to images of Syrians dying in a large-scale chemical weapons attack, Samantha Power was quietly pushing President Obama for a military strike to stop what she calls the “grotesque tactics” of President Bashar al-Assad. For a fleeting moment this month, it seemed she had prevailed.

articles.headline: Honors for ‘Breaking Bad’ and ‘Modern Family’
articles.snippet: It was a night of upsets at the 65th Primetime Emmy Awards, in which several HBO series won unexpected victories.
articles.abstract: It was a night of upsets at the 65th Primetime Emmy Awards, in which several HBO series won unexpected victories.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — On Sunday, a mere seven days before its very last episode, AMC’s “Breaking Bad” finally earned the outstanding drama Emmy award that it had been denied for years.
